awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: A Posteriori Error Analysis for Complex Models with Applications to Efficient Numerical Solution and Uncertainty Quantification
awd_abstract_narration:
Many scientific and engineering problems of importance to the nation's infrastructure and defense are concerned with multi-physics systems in which multiple physical processes interact in complex ways. An important example is the flow of a liquid transporting reacting chemicals in which the reaction affects the fluid properties of the liquid. Such reacting flows arise in applications ranging from biological systems to combustion processes associated with energy use. In general, the complexity of multi-physics systems prevents direct experimental observation of crucial features. Thus their study depends critically on computing approximate solutions of mathematical models describing the processes and their interactions. However, such simulations strain the computational capabilities of the most powerful computers and consequently, computational errors in the approximations are always significant and may be overwhelming. Over two decades, the project investigators have developed a systematic approach for producing accurate computational estimates of the error of approximate solutions of models of multi-physics systems. In this project, the investigators explore the use of error estimates from this approach to guide the efficient use of computational resources in order to maximize the fidelity of approximate solutions of multi-physics systems. They also apply the error estimates to accurately quantify the uncertainty in predictions of behavior of multi-physics systems based on the approximate solutions of models. The results of this project will enhance the ability of the nation's engineers and scientists to investigate and predict the behavior of complex physical systems important to the nation's security and infrastructure. 


This project tackles critical problems associated with using sophisticated cutting-edge multi-discretization numerical methods for multiscale, multiphysics models to pursue scientific inference and engineering design.  The research is based on a posteriori error analysis for multi-physics, multi-discretization problems that quantifies the effects of a wide variety of discretization steps through the use of adjoint problems and computable residuals. The primary focus of the project is twofold: (1) Developing and analyzing methods for using accurate error estimates to guide discretization choices in order to achieve a desired accuracy at roughly minimal computational cost; and (2) Investigating how to extend accurate error estimation methods to address uncertainty quantification for multiphysics systems, where 'discretization' includes the sampling of a random process and the overall error is a combination of discretization and sampling errors. The investigators pursue the development of novel multi-stage approaches to the construction of efficient numerical solutions and the extension of a posteriori error analysis to statistical computations. The project also involves the extension of the theory of a posteriori error analysis to hyperbolic problems and nonstandard quantities of interest.

por.por_cntn:
Partial differential equations (PDEs) provide mathematical models for a wide range of physical phenomena from laboratory to geospatial scales. Analytic solutions to partial differential equations are limited to a small number of examples, and solutions to PDEs are commonly sought via computation. Numerical computations, in turn, are often conducted to seek specific information, a so-called “quantity of interest”, such as the concentration of a chemical species (or temperature) at a particular physical location, or the drag exerted by the flow around an object. Adjoint-based a posteriori techniques can provide estimates of the errors in the numerical computation of such quantities of interest. Further, they can assign contributions to this error resulting from various choices made for the solution approach, such as the spatial and temporal resolution at which the computation is performed, and can therefore direct discretization choices so as to achieve a desired level of accuracy in the quantity of interest. As well as for one-time calculations, accurate error estimates are essential for effective uncertainty quantification since the behavior and sources of error can vary widely according to the values of the parameters of the PDE.

Increases in the size of problems to be solved, coupled with modern computer architectures, have made solutions using multiple processors simultaneously, so-called “parallel” computational approaches, increasingly attractive. Domain decomposition methods are iterative techniques that divide the spatial domain into regions that may be solved simultaneously (in parallel), and are very well established. Iterative techniques that divide time in to regions that may be solved in parallel are less commonly employed. Parallelization in both space and time effectively utilizes modern high-performance computer architectures, but introduces additional errors.  Accurate computation requires a delicate balance between spatial, temporal and iterative errors, and successful solution strategies must take these distinct sources of error into account. Our new error analysis is able to disaggregate the spatial and temporal discretization errors, as well as identify additional errors resulting from the iterative procedures in both space and time, resulting in solution strategies that control all sources of error.

Commonly, the time at which a functional of the solution achieves a threshold value, which we refer to as the time to an “event”, is the primary focus for the computational study of a physical system. Examples include the time at which the concentration of a chemical species (or temperature) reaches a critical value at a particular location, or the time at which a traveling wave reaches a certain height at a specific location. We have developed and implemented new, highly accurate approaches for estimating the error in the computed time to a given event.

A posteriori error estimation for parallel, iterative method, and in particular for overlapping domain decomposition, can appear very technical in the context of partial differential equations, and the essential underlying ideas can be obscured. However, these ideas become obvious when viewed in the context of solving a system of linear algebraic equations. The project undertaken with undergraduate student Andre Leautaud explains our analysis technique applied to a system of linear algebraic equations, and provides both Matlab and python codes.  A description of this work and all codes can be found at the Github site https://github.com/AndreLeautaud/Domain-Decomposition.

Bayesian inverse problems in the context of differential equations seek to determine the probability distribution of the (input) parameters of a differential equation modeling a physical system based on observations (outputs) of the system. Most techniques require repeated solutions of the differential equation model at many different values of the parameters. Standard numerical approximation techniques use estimates of the local truncation error to determine the accuracy with which the differential equation should be solved. Adjoint-based a posteriori error techniques can provide the error in the likelihood function for the observed data, and provide a theoretically justifiable basis for making discretization choices when solving the differential equation. We have shown how embedding adaptive solution strategies based on the error in the likelihood provide efficiencies within the established No-U-Turn, Markov Chain Monte Carlo (NUTS) algorithm. This work was conducted in collaboration with a team at Oxford University including graduate student Richard Creswell, a US citizen, who completed his D. Phil at Oxford in 2022.

During the course of this work, Colorado State University student Christina Rigsby successfully defended her MS thesis “An analysis of domain decomposition methods using DEAL.II”, in fall 2020. Christina is currently continuing her PhD studies in mathematics at Colorado State University.

Publications addressing the discretization errors in the time to “events” in ordinary and partial differential equations represent collaborations with PhD students Zachary Stevens and Trevor Giannini respectively, at the University of New Mexico. Zachary Stevens defended is PhD thesis “Robust uncertainty quantification with analysis of error in standard and non-standard quantities of interest”,  in July 2022. Trevor Giannini plans to submit and defend his thesis in 2023.
